title.narrative: Emergency Shelter response to conflict-induced displacement for disaster affected IDPs in Non-Governmental Controlled Area, Kachin State and Northern Shan State.

description.narrative: The project will mainly focus on shelter construction for newly displaced persons in Non-Government Controlled Area and Government Controlled Area with a total population of 11,000 situated in Kachin and Shan State where IDP have been internally displaced at the end of 2016 when the Tatmadaw has fired up KIA. Through the effect of bomb blasts, IDPs from Munggazup/Zai Aung Camp were scattered in villages and some tried to flee to China side. Currently, they are displaced with emergency helps from Local NGOs and INGOs in Sha it yang Camp. Based on the current report from IRRC, it is expected that IDPs will be remaining in Sha it yang for some years as this place is the place where they can settle down for temporarily. Though there are around 420 Households who are in need of shelters in Shaityang, This project will construct 203 new temporary shelters both in Shaityang camp (for 166 HH) and Mai Hkawng KBC camp (for 37 HH).Currently, IRRC (IDP and Refugee Relief Committee) of KIO makes land preparation for shelter construction. Each household will get 40ftx60ft land. According to preliminary findings of JST to Newly Displaced IDPs, majority of the respondent answered that their current camp is partially safe KCA 26% said not safe at all. If there is no more fighting, it is safe. There are protection findings from Sha it yang only which is extracted from JST overall assessment database. Respondents (72% female/28% male) from Sha it yang said as follow Q: Was moving to a new site/location voluntary? A: - 98% said that they were moving as voluntary. Safety and security 79 % said that completely safe or partially safe in Sha it yang. Q:- Do you feel safer in the new site/location compared to the old camp? A:- 78 % said that a lot safer or slightly safer. Q:- Do you have security concern at the moment? A:- 71% said that they have no security concern. Q:- How long do you think you will stay in you new location/camp? A:- 43% said that they will stay as permanent and 8% said that they will be as temporary. Q:- What kind of violence or harassment is prevalent in the camp? A:- 0.5% said that there will be prevalent of child labor or recruitment of child soldiers and 1% said that there will be prevalent of violence against women. 82% said that they know where to go file complaints about abuses in Sha it yang. 49% said that their preference place is original village and 29% said that their preference place is staying in current location. According to respondents it could say 80% is safer and suitable to live in Sha it yang. Currently, IRRC (IDP and Refugee Relief Committee) of KIO is doing land preparation for shelter construction. Each household will get 40ftx60ft land. In Banmaw Township, there are 37 Households from six different villages who are newly displaced in Mai Hkawng KBC camp. As they are right now displaced in emergency tents, they are in need of temporary shelters. The shelter interventions will address the highest priority needs within Kachin and Shan based on the shelter/NFI/CCCM cluster prioritization. Using a participatory approach, the camp management committee of each camp will be consulted to ensure the interventions meet the differential needs of men, women, boys, girls of different ages and disparities.
